H0.text: The information on the strand always changes when the nucleotides in a strand of DNA are rearranged.

H1.text: The mass of the strand changes whenever the nucleotides in a strand of DNA are rearranged.

H2.text: The organism dies when the nucleotides in a strand of DNA are rearranged.

H3.text: The organism always thrives when the nucleotides in a strand of DNA are rearranged.

A4.text: Insertions in the coding region of a gene may alter splicing of the mRNA (splice site mutation), or cause a shift in the reading frame (frameshift), both of which can significantly alter the gene product.

A5.text: Mutations in the non-coding regulatory sequences can alter levels of gene expression, which affects the functional information encoded by the DNA strand.

A6.text: Daughter cells that inherit these wrong bases carry mutations from which the original DNA sequence is unrecoverable (except in the rare case of a back mutation, for example, through gene conversion).

A7.text: Gene conversion occurs at high frequency at the actual site of the recombination event during meiosis. It is a process by which a DNA sequence is copied from one DNA helix (which remains unchanged) to another DNA helix, whose sequence is altered.

A8.text: Chromosomal crossover leads to offspring having different combinations of genes from those of their parents, and can occasionally produce new chimeric alleles.
